questions.text: A 43-year-old woman is evaluated for 3-months of muscle weakness. The patient reports that the weakness is most prominent in the shoulders and hips. She works as a barber and is having difficulty keeping her arms raised while cutting hair. Temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), blood pressure is 117/68 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and respiratory rate is 11/min. Physical examination is notable for weakness and tenderness to light palpation in the large muscles of the extremities. No rashes are observed on the patient’s body. A proximal thigh muscle biopsy is performed. What cellular type and infiltration pattern would be most likely found on muscle biopsy?
questions.solution:
Polymyositis is an idiopathic inflammatory myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness. The pelvic and shoulder muscles are most commonly affected. This weakness can present with difficulty rising from a chair, lifting one’s arms, climbing stairs, or combing one’s hair. Sometimes, the patient’s muscles may be tender or painful. In severe cases, the muscles of the pharynx and esophagus are involved, resulting in dysphagia. Skin findings are absent in patients with polymyositis.  

Polymyositis is an autoimmune condition which occurs when cytotoxic (CD8+) T-cells are inappropriately activated by normal muscle proteins. The cytotoxic T-cells attack muscle cells, resulting in their apoptosis. The specific antigenic targets in polymyositis include tRNA synthetases, also called Jo-1, a nuclear protein known as Mi-2, and components of the signal-recognition particle (SRP) which helps with proteins trafficking within the cell. The destruction of muscle cells can lead to muscle weakness and can cause muscle enzymes, such as aldolase and creatine kinase to spill into the blood, resulting in elevated laboratory values.  

Muscle biopsies are often performed in the work-up of polymyositis and reveal endomysial infiltration (infiltration of the sheath surrounding individual muscle fibers) by CD8+ T-cells.  




Option Analysis

❌  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern CD4+ lymphocytes  Perimysial :
Incorrect: Perimysial infiltration by CD4+ T-cells would be observed in dermatomyositis. This condition typically presents with proximal muscle weakness and skin findings (e.g., heliotrope rash, Gottron papules, etc.) While the patient has proximal muscle weakness, the absence of skin findings on physical examination makes dermatomyositis less likely. 
❌  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern CD4+ lymphocytes  Endomysial:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis is characterized by CD4+ T-cell infiltration. However, dermatomyositis presents with a perimysial infiltration pattern. This means that the lymphocytes infiltrate the connective tissue sheath that groups muscle fibers into bundles.
❌  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern  CD8+ lymphocytes Perimysial :
Incorrect: Infiltration by CD8+ lymphocytes would be observed in polymyositis. This condition presents with proximal muscle weakness but no cutaneous findings, which is consistent with the patient’s presentation. However, polymyositis presents with an endomysial infiltration pattern. This means that the lymphocytes infiltrate the connective tissue that ensheath individual muscle fibers. 
✅  Cellular Type Infiltration Pattern  CD8+ lymphocytes  Endomysial  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌   Cellular Type  Infiltration Pattern  Eosinophils Perimysial :
Incorrect: Eosinophilic infiltration may be observed in vasculitides such as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly called Churg-Strauss syndrome). Vasculitides can also present with cutaneous symptoms and potentially muscle weakness secondary to systemic inflammation. However, Churg-Strauss syndrome and similar conditions also present with respiratory tract symptoms, as well as renal involvement.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of facial muscle weakness that started two months ago. He complains of difficulty chewing halfway through a meal that is associated with difficulty swallowing. He also reports “seeing-double,” usually at the end of the day. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. He takes hydrochlorothiazide and metformin. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 72/min and blood pressure is 148/83 mmHg. During the physical examination, the patient is asked to look upwards toward the ceiling for 60 seconds. This maneuver elicits bilateral diplopia, which resolves after several minutes of rest. Neck and cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a serum creatinine kinase of 65 U/L. Work-up should be initiated for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
This patient with fatigable chewing, dysphagia and diplopia that is exacerbated with activity most likely has myasthenia gravis (MG), an autoimmune condition that causes varying degrees of skeletal muscle weakness. The condition has a bimodal distribution, most commonly affecting women in their 20s and 30s and men in their 60s and 70s. It occurs due to the formation of autoantibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors on muscle cells.  

The hallmark symptom is muscle weakness that worsens after repeated activity and improves after rest. Patients may complain of ptosis and diplopia secondary to extraocular muscle weakness early in the course of the disease. Later on, bulbar muscles involvement can result in slurred speech, difficulty chewing, and choking. Neck muscles involvement can cause patients to feel that their head is heavy and difficult to keep upright. Lastly, involvement of the proximal limb muscles can result in difficulty climbing stairs, combing hair, or brushing teeth.    

Approximately 75% of patients with MG have associated thymic abnormalities (e.g., thymic hyperplasia, thymoma), and mediastinal imaging should be performed in every patient to actively rule them out. Other less common associations of MG include bronchogenic carcinoma, hyperthyroidism, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Option Analysis

✅ Thymoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Polymyositis:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is an inflammatory myopathy that most often affects proximal muscles, such as those in the hip and shoulder. In contrast, it would be atypical for polymyositis to predominantly affect the extraocular muscles. Moreover, patients with polymyositis will generally have elevated creatinine kinase levels, whereas this patient’s level is normal.
❌ Small cell lung cancer:
Incorrect: Patients with small cell lung cancer can develop Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which occurs when auto-antibodies develop against presynaptic calcium channels. LEMS manifests with muscle weakness that improves with activity. In contrast, this patient has muscle weakness that is exacerbated by activity, which is more consistent with myasthenia gravis.
❌ Cushing disease:
Incorrect: Cushing disease is a state of hypercortisolism secondary to ACTH overproduction by a pituitary adenoma. Patients may experience muscle atrophy and weakness, but these symptoms are usually accompanied by thin extremities/truncal obesity due to fat redistribution, abdominal striae, and headaches, none of which are seen in this patient.
❌ Multiple sclerosis:
Incorrect: Common ocular findings in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) include optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia (which can cause diplopia) and nystagmus, though extraocular muscle weakness can sometimes occur. The condition is usually associated with sensory abnormalities (e.g. numbness), cognitive impairment, and autonomic dysfunction, none of which are seen in this patient. Moreover, MS most often affects young females.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider because of a chronic cough for the past 3 months. It is occasionally accompanied by flecks of blood-tinged sputum. Review of systems is significant for weakness in the hips and thighs bilaterally and 15 lbs (6.8 kg) weight loss. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. He only takes hydrochlorothiazide. Social history is notable for a 50-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min and blood pressure is 157/85 mmHg. Pulmonary examination reveals expiratory wheezing on the left side in 5th intercostal space. A chest radiograph is ordered and reveals the following:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia.org   

Laboratory testing reveals a creatinine kinase level of 75 U/L. Which of the following additional examination findings will most likely be present in this patient?

choices.text: Reduced deep tendon reflexes that transiently improve with repeated activity
Presence of multiple newly-erupted seborrheic keratoses
Hallux dorsiflexion with stimulation of the sole of the foot
Tenderness of the shoulder and hip muscles

questions.solution:
This patient with chronic cough that is occasionally productive of blood-tinged sputum, and weight loss, together with radiographic evidence of a left-sided central hilar mass is highly suspicious of a lung malignancy. His proximal lower extremity weakness is most likely secondary to Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), which is associated with small cell lung cancer.

Although LEMS is a clinical diagnosis, it can be confirmed via laboratory testing, which may reveal the presence of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels. Repeated nerve stimulation will reveal an incremental increase in the muscle action potential. Once the diagnosis has been made, a chest CT should be performed to evaluate for underlying small cell lung cancer, with which it is most commonly associated.

Treatment depends on the underlying cause. If there is small cell lung cancer, treatment of the cancer is the main goal. When there is no underlying malignancy, amifampridine (3,4-diaminopyridine) can be used to block neuronal potassium channels, prolong the depolarization phase, and increase the amount of acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction. Guanidine can also be used as a second line agent. In severe cases, immunosuppressants, intravenous immunoglobulin therapy (IVIG) and plasma exchange can be used to remove the autoantibodies.



Option Analysis

✅ Reduced deep tendon reflexes that transiently improve with repeated activity:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Presence of multiple newly-erupted seborrheic keratoses:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the Leser-Trelat sign. The condition is associated with malignancies of the gastrointestinal tract, such as stomach or colorectal cancer. It would be atypical for this condition to manifest in a patient with lung cancer and would not account for the patient’s muscle weakness.  
❌ Hallux dorsiflexion with stimulation of the sole of the foot:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes a positive Babinski sign. It is seen in conditions affecting the upper motor neurons, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). However, ALS manifests with asymmetrical limb weakness. Moreover, this patient’s history of bloody sputum and imaging findings are consistent with lung cancer, making LEMS aore likely explanation for the muscle weakness.  
❌ Tenderness of the shoulder and hip muscles:
Incorrect: Dermatomyositis and polymyositis are inflammatory myopathies that can manifest with tenderness in the proximal muscles. Dermatomyositis in particular is associated with many malignancies, such as lung, ovarian, and stomach cancer. However, patients with inflammatory myopathies will likely have elevated creatinine kinase levels secondary to muscle injury, which is not seen in this patient.
❌ Jaw pain exacerbated by chewing:
Incorrect: This is seen in patients with temporal arteritis. Patients with this condition can also develop polymyalgia rheumatica, which manifests with muscle pain, stiffness, and subjective weakness that is most prominent at the shoulder and hip joints. However, neither temporal arteritis nor polymyalgia rheumatica is associated with lung cancer.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man comes to the outpatient provider because of a 5-month history of weakness in the shoulders and hip muscles. The patient reports having difficulty getting out of a chair and climbing stairs. The patient has no other medical conditions and previously led an active lifestyle. Temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 122/68 mmHg, pulse is 67/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. Physical examination is notable for tenderness and weakness in the shoulder and hip muscles. The following is also noted on bilateral ocular examination:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following findings is most specific to the patient’s condition?

choices.text: Muscle biopsy revealing perimysial CD4+ lymphocyte infiltration
Muscle biopsy revealing endomysial CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration
Radiograph revealing vertebral body erosion with reactive sclerosis

questions.solution:
Dermatomyositis is an antibody-mediated autoimmune myopathy characterized by proximal skeletal muscle weakness and skin findings. The pelvic and shoulder muscles are most commonly affected. This weakness can present as difficult rising from a chair, lifting one’s arms, climbing stairs, or combing one’s hair.  

Several skin findings may be present. A purplish rash on the upper eyelids, called a “heliotrope rash,” can often be observed. Patients can also have the “shawl sign,” which is a rash involving the shoulders, upper chest, and back. Less commonly, the patient may have a malar rash (erythema of the cheeks and bridge of the nose with sparing of the nasolabial folds), classically in the shape of butterfly. Another classic finding is the Gottron sign which consists of flat, red, scaly papules over the back of the fingers, elbows, or knees.  

Dermatomyositis occurs when the body produces self-antibodies against autoantigens in the muscle and skin. Many of the autoantibodies attach to endothelial cells lining the capillaries near the perimysium (connective tissue sheath surrounding groups of muscle fibers). This process activates the complement cascade and causes the targeted cells to lyse. Dermatomyositis can occur secondarily as a paraneoplastic syndrome of an underlying malignancy, such as Hodgkin lymphoma as well as lung, stomach, colorectal, and ovarian cancer; therefore, patients with additional constitutional symptoms (e.g., fever, weight loss, night sweats) should be suspected of having an underlying malignancy.    .

Muscle biopsies are often performed in the work-up and reveal perimysial infiltration. Given the condition’s antibody-mediated pathogenesis, the infiltrate will consist of CD4+ T-cells (which regulate antibody production) and antibody-producing B-cells.   


Option Analysis

✅ Muscle biopsy revealing perimysial CD4+ lymphocyte infiltration:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Muscle biopsy revealing endomysial CD8+ lymphocyte infiltration:
 Incorrect: Endomysial infiltration by CD8+ lymphocytes is consistent with the presentation of polymyositis. Polymyositis also presents with proximal muscle weakness, most often affecting the hips and shoulders. However, polymyositis does not present with skin findings, whereas this patient’s physical examination reveals a heliotrope rash on the eyelids.  
❌ Elevated serum creatinine kinase level:
Incorrect: Increased serum creatinine kinase levels would be expected in pathologies that cause muscle injury. These include trauma, rhabdomyolysis, and autoimmune myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. However, this finding is non-specific and would have limited utility in distinguishing this patient’s likely diagnosis (dermatomyositis) from other conditions with a similar presentation.
❌ Elevated peripheral blood eosinophil count:
Incorrect: Eosinophilic infiltration may be observed in vasculitides such as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). This condition was formerly named Churg-Strauss syndrome. EGPA can manifest with skin symptoms and potentially muscle weakness secondary to systemic inflammation. However, patients with EGPA would be expected to also have respiratory symptoms such as sinusitis and asthma.
❌ Radiograph revealing vertebral body erosion with reactive sclerosis:
Incorrect: This finding is termed the “bamboo sign” and found in patients with ankylosing spondylitis. The condition most often affects young men and presents with back pain that is worse in the morning. Ankylosing spondylitis can also affect the hip and shoulder joints, which may account for the tenderness noted on physical exam. However, it would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to present with the purple-red eyelid rash observed in this patient.

questions.text:
A 67-year-old woman comes to the outpatient provider for evaluation of fatigue and muscular pain for the past 4 months. The patient also reports muscle stiffness that is worse when waking up in the morning and improves after several hours. Family history is notable for rheumatoid arthritis in the patient’s mother. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg, pulse is 68/min, and respiratory rate is 12/min. There is tenderness to palpation in the muscles of the bilateral shoulders and hips. No muscle weakness is noted. Laboratory testing reveals the following results:  
 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.7 g/dL 
 Leukocyte  7,900/mm3 
 Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR)   105 mm/h 
 Serum creatinine kinase  76 U/L 

Which of the following symptoms is the patient at the greatest risk of developing?

choices.text: Ulnar deviation of the bilateral wrists
Purplish discoloration and swelling of the bilateral eyelids
Localized jaw pain that is exacerbated by chewing
Knee pain that is exacerbated by physical activity

questions.solution:
This patient has polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR). It is an inflammatory disease that often affects patients (women>men) over 50 years of age. The condition causes symptoms like pain and stiffness of the shoulder and hip, which often starts on one side, but typically progresses to both sides within weeks. The symptoms are usually more severe in the morning and at night, often lasting for more than an hour, and they typically improve after activity. Morning stiffness in PMR is always present, and its absence excludes the diagnosis of PMR. The pain can make it hard to get out of bed or up from a chair, and lifting the arms above shoulder height can be difficult. It can also cause a low-grade fever, fatigue, and loss of appetite which can lead to weight loss.  

Many patients with PMR can develop temporal arteritis. Temporal arteritis causes inflammation of the body’s large- and medium-sized arteries, including the carotid arteries, its major branches, and the aorta. The condition can present with symptoms including headaches, jaw claudication and visual disturbances. Jaw claudication is a very common symptom and can be seen in over 50% of patients with temporal arteritis. Since temporal arteritis affects the internal carotid artery, it can affect the branches, including the ophthalmic artery; therefore, the most feared complication of GCA is permanent loss of vision, which commonly is painless and sudden, can be partial or complete, and can be unilateral or bilateral. In contrast to other symptoms, vision loss only occurs in 10% of patients.    

Option Analysis

❌ Ulnar deviation of the bilateral wrists:
Incorrect: Ulnar deviation would be observed in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA), an autoimmune condition characterized by joint pain, swelling, and synovial destruction. The patient’s family history puts her at increased risk of developing RA. Patients with RA can present with morning stiffness. The condition most often affects distal joints (e.g., metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, wrist, knee). In contrast, it would be atypical for RA to present with muscle tenderness at the shoulders and hips.
❌ Purplish discoloration and swelling of the bilateral eyelids:
Incorrect: This answer describes a heliotrope rash. The condition is observed in patients with dermatomyositis, which can also present with proximal muscle tenderness. Patients with dermatomyositis also have muscle weakness and an elevated serum creatinine kinase. In contrast, this patient has no muscle weakness and a serum creatinine kinase within normal range.
❌ Permanent monocular vision loss:
Incorrect: The patient has proximal muscle tenderness but no weakness and a normal creatinine kinase. This presentation is consistent with polymyalgia rheumatica. Patients with this condition are at increased risk of developing temporal arteritis, which can cause headaches, jaw pain, and permanent vision loss. However, the incidence of irreversible vision damage is low (12%) when compared with other symptoms. For instance, over 80% of patients complain of headaches and over 40% complain of jaw pain/difficulty chewing. 
✅ Localized jaw pain that is exacerbated by chewing:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Knee pain that is exacerbated by physical activity:
Incorrect: Osteoarthritis presents with pain in weight-bearing joints. The pain worsens with activity and improves with rest. In contrast, this patient’s pain is worse in the morning and subsequently improves throughout the day. Moreover, osteoarthritis would not explain the patient’s fever and elevated ESR.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider because of facial muscle weakness that began about four months ago. She reports having intermittent episodes of drooping of eyelids and difficulty chewing food, which usually happen in the evenings and resolve the subsequent morning. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. She takes amlodipine. Social history is notable for a 20-pack-year smoking history. Family history is notable for systemic lupus erythematosus in her older sister. In the office, her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 146/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is observed to have drooping of the left eyelid and impaired adduction of the right eye. The findings appear to be exacerbated by repeated muscle use. Antibodies against which of the following components will most likely be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient with ptosis, extraocular muscle weakness and fatigable chewing most likely has myasthenia gravis (MG). The hallmark symptom is muscle weakness that worsens after repeated activity and improves after rest (as in this patient).

The first step in work-up for this autoimmune condition is to test for the presence of anti-acetylcholine receptor antibodies. However, it is worthy to note that around a quarter of patients may test negative. As a result, these individuals should also be tested for the presence of muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase antibodies.

In patients with high clinical suspicion but negative antibody test results, single-fiber electromyography should be performed. The test involves repeatedly stimulating a muscle via electrical stimuli. In patients with MG, there will be a progressive decline in the muscle action potential with repeated stimulation.  Once MG is diagnosed, further workup should be tailored towards ruling out the disorders that are frequently associated with MG. For instance, thyroid function tests should be performed to rule out associated Graves disease. Similarly, chest CT/MRI should be performed to check for thymic hyperplasia or thymoma.

Option Analysis

❌ Double-stranded DNA:
Incorrect: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) can be positive for anti-dsDNA antibodies. SLE often manifests with a malar rash, photosensitivity, and arthritis. In contrast, it would be atypical for SLE to cause isolated extraocular and bulbar muscle weakness. 
❌ Histidyl tRNA synthetase:
Incorrect: Anti-histidyl tRNA synthetase antibodies may be seen in patients with polymyositis. It is an inflammatory myopathy that frequently affects proximal muscles, such as those in the hip and shoulder. It would be atypical for polymyositis to predominantly affect the extraocular and bulbar muscles.
❌ Voltage-gated calcium channel:
Incorrect: Patients with Lambert-Eaton syndrome develop antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels. The condition can cause weakness in the proximal extremities and oculobulbar muscles that temporarily improves with repeated use. In contrast, this patient has muscle weakness that worsens with use, which is more consistent with the presentation of MG.  
❌ Ganglioside proteins:
Incorrect: Antibodies against ganglioside proteins (anti-GQ1b) are found in patients with Miller-Fisher syndrome, a variant of Guillain-Barre syndrome that can manifest with acute ophthalmoplegia, areflexia, and ataxia in the setting of a preceding bacterial or viral infection. In contrast, this patient has no recent history of infection. Moreover, it would be unusual for it to present with intermittent episodes of muscle weakness that are exacerbated by activity and improve with rest.
✅ Postsynaptic acetylcholine receptor:
Correct: See Main Explanation

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman begins complaining of dyspnea while recovering in the post-anesthesia care unit. Earlier in the day, the patient underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy for treatment of symptomatic gallstones. Past medical history is unremarkable. Her temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), pulse is 93/min, respiratory rate is 24/min and blood pressure is 125/72 mmHg. Physical examination shows the patient in distress with shallow breaths, using accessory muscles. In addition, the patient is observed to have drooping of the eyelids and corners of the mouth bilaterally. Pupils are 3 cm bilaterally and reactive to light. An arterial blood gas measurement reveals the following findings:
 
Laboratory Value  Result
 pH  7.31 
 PaCO2  56 mmHg 
 PaO2  71 mmHg 
 Bicarbonate  25 mmol/L 

The patient’s condition improves with administration of edrophonium chloride. Which of the following best describes the cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Lodging of blood clot in the pulmonary vasculature

questions.solution:
This patient with significant respiratory distress (dyspnea, rapid, shallow breath, use of accessory muscles) and respiratory acidosis (↓pH, ↑pCO2, ↓O2, normal HCO3), together with examination findings of ptosis and facial drooping, is most likely in myasthenic crisis.

Myasthenic crisis is a life-threatening complication of myasthenia gravis (MG) that occurs due to weakness of the respiratory muscles (e.g., diaphragm, intercostal muscles). It can be triggered by infections, surgery/anesthesia, pregnancy, and medications such as beta-blockers. The condition manifests with dyspnea and respiratory insufficiency, which can quickly progress to respiratory failure.  

It is important to distinguish a myasthenic crisis from a cholinergic crisis, which occurs due to overtreatment of MG by acetylcholinerase inhibitors (e.g. pyridostigmine). In a cholinergic crisis, too much acetylcholine is present at the neuromuscular junction. Both cholinergic crisis and myasthenic crisis manifest with similar symptoms, so an edrophonium test is needed to distinguish the two. Administration of edrophonium briefly blocks the breakdown of acetylcholine, temporarily increasing its levels at the neuromuscular junction. In myasthenic crisis, the increased acetylcholine levels are enough to overcome the symptoms caused by the decreased number of available receptors, so muscle weakness improves. If symptoms get worse, a cholinergic crisis should be suspected.  



Option Analysis

❌ Cholinomimetic drug overdose:
Incorrect: Overdose of cholinomimetic medications can result in a cholinergic crisis. The condition can cause cramping, muscle weakness, and paralysis, which can lead to respiratory failure. However, patients experiencing a cholinergic crisis will also have miosis and muscle weakness that worsens after edrophonium administration. In contrast, this patient has normal-sized pupils and weakness that improved after edrophonium administration.
❌ Deflation of lung alveoli :
Incorrect: This answer choice describes atelectasis, a condition that can arise in postoperative patients. Postoperative pain, retained airway secretions, and reduced spontaneous breathing secondary to anesthesia are all precipitating factors in the development of atelectasis. However, this patient also has ptosis and bulbar muscle weakness, which raise concern for myasthenic crisis instead.
✅ Respiratory muscles weakness:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Lodging of blood clot in the pulmonary vasculature:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes pulmonary embolism, which can manifest with dyspnea and tachycardia. Recent surgery and associated immobilization can predispose patients to developing this condition. However, pulmonary embolism would not account for the extraocular and facial muscle weakness noted on the physical exam.
❌ Pulmonary edema secondary to inflammation:
Incorrect: Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is characterized by a severe inflammatory reaction that damages the lungs, increases vessel permeability, and causes fluid to accumulate in the lungs. The condition is often triggered by conditions such as sepsis, pneumonia, and pancreatitis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette does not have any of these risk factors.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man comes to his primary care provider for evaluation of muscle weakness. The symptoms began four months ago. The patient reports the weakness is most prominent in the thighs. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and type I diabetes mellitus, for which he takes daily amlodipine and insulin injections. Social history is notable for a 40-pack-year smoking history. In the office, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 71/min, and blood pressure is 152/83 mmHg. Physical examination shows weakness in the quadriceps bilaterally and 3/5 patellar reflexes. The patient is asked to walk back-and-forth several times across the examination room. Repeat testing reveals 5/5 patellar reflexes. No sensory deficits are observed. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. Laboratory testing reveals a creatinine kinase of 80 U/L and erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Which of the following best describes the pathophysiology of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Formation of antibodies against acetylcholine receptors
T-cell mediated damage of muscle tissue
Impaired release of acetylcholine from motor end plate
Formation of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.solution:
This patient has Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS), an autoimmune condition characterized by the formation of auto-antibodies against presynaptic voltage-gated calcium channels. It is a type II hypersensitivity reaction.  

The antibodies bind and block the channels, leaving only a few that are viable. As a result, only small quantities of calcium can enter the neuron, which is not enough to trigger acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction and induce muscle contractions. With repeated stimulation by electrical impulses from the brain, enough calcium will finally make it through the few free calcium channels, resulting in acetylcholine release and muscle contraction.

Hence, patients with LEMS exhibit the “warming-up phenomenon,” which is muscle weakness that temporarily improves after repeated use (as in this patient). The disease most commonly leads to symmetrical weakness of the proximal muscles, such as those in the shoulders and hips. The lower limbs are more frequently affected. As a result, patients may endorse difficulty climbing stairs, standing up from a sitting position, and lifting their arm to brush their hair.

In addition, patients can have reduced tendon reflexes and autonomic symptoms, such as dry mouth, constipation, and blurry vision.



Option Analysis

❌ Formation of antibodies against acetylcholine receptors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes myasthenia gravis, which most often affects the oculobulbar muscles. The condition manifests with muscle weakness that is exacerbated by repeated use. In contrast, this patient has weakness most prominent in the proximal leg muscles and decreased tendon reflexes that improve with repeated muscle use. These symptoms are more consistent with Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome.
❌ T-cell mediated damage of muscle tissue:
Incorrect: Polymyositis is characterized by cell-mediated autoimmune damage of muscle tissue. The condition causes proximal muscle weakness. However, polymyositis would manifest with an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, due to its inflammation, and elevated creatinine kinase, due to muscle damage.  
❌ Impaired release of acetylcholine from motor end plate:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes botulism, which can manifest with a flaccid descending paralysis, diplopia, and dysarthria/dysphagia. In adults, the condition is often caused by the consumption of canned foods contaminated by botulinum toxin or infection of a wound by Clostridium botulinum spores. However, it would be atypical for botulism to present with muscle weakness most prominent in the thighs or reduced deep tendon reflexes that improve with activity.  
✅ Formation of antibodies against voltage-gated calcium channels:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Autoimmune damage of Schwann cells:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS), which causes an ascending flaccid paralysis and reduced deep tendon reflexes. The condition also typically causes reduced sensation in the hands and feet. In contrast, this patient has no sensory deficits. Moreover, it would be atypical for GBS to present with reduced tendon reflexes that improve after repeated stimulation.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man comes to the primary care physician’s office for evaluation of fatigue and muscle weakness for the past 6 months. The patient is a construction worker and reports having difficulty lifting as much as he previously could. Past medical history is notable for asthma managed with albuterol and budesonide inhalers. He consumes 3-4 glasses of beer per week and is sexually active with his spouse. Physical examination reveals 4/5 strength in the shoulders and hips and 5/5 in the rest of the body. The deltoids and quadriceps are tender to palpation. Examination of the patient’s hands reveals the following:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Which of the following additional cutaneous findings would most likely be observed on the patient’s physical exam?

choices.text: Diffuse lace-like discoloration of the skin
Scale-like papules and plaques on the elbows and knees
Wide reddish-purple streaks on the abdomen
Pruritic eruptions on the body’s skin flexures

questions.solution:
The patient in this vignette has dermatomyositis. It is an antibody-mediated autoimmune condition characterized by proximal muscle weakness and cutaneous findings. The four classic skin findings found in patients with dermatomyositis are: Gottron papules, heliotrope rash, shawl and face rash, and mechanic hands.  

 1) A heliotrope rash (Figure 1A) is characterized by a purplish-red discoloration that most often affects the upper eyelids. Periorbital edema is usually present as well. In some cases, the rash can also affect the nose and cheeks.  

2) Gottron papules (Figure 1B) are erythematous macules or patches over extensor surfaces of elbows, knuckles, knees, and ankles. The image in this vignette shows Gottron papules on the patient’s hands.  

3) The  shawl sign (Figure 1C) is a widespread, flat, reddened area that appears on the back, shoulders, and upper chest. Exposure to ultraviolet light can exacerbate the rash. Patients may have concurrent redness of the face.  

4) Mechanic hands (Figure 1D) refers to hyperkeratotic, scaling, and fissuring of the patient’s hands. It most often affects the fingers and palms. The prevalence of this finding amongst patients with dermatomyositis is low. However, it is frequently tested on board exams.  

Figure 1: Cutaneous manifestations of dermatomyositis

Images reproduced from Wikimedia Commons (A, B, C, D)

Option Analysis

❌ Diffuse lace-like discoloration of the skin:
Incorrect: This answer describes livedo reticularis, a condition caused by swelling of the venules secondary to obstruction by clots. Livedo reticularis can be seen in many autoimmune conditions that damage the blood vessels, including polyarteritis nodosa, systemic lupus erythematosus, and dermatomyositis. This patient’s hand findings (Gotrron papules) and proximal weakness are consistent with dermatomyositis. However, the incidence of livedo reticularis is low amongst patients with dermatomyositis.
❌ Scale-like papules and plaques on the elbows and knees :
Incorrect: This answer describes psoriasis, an idiopathic chronic inflammatory condition characterized by increased keratinocyte proliferation. Individuals with psoriasis have silvery plaques found on extensor surfaces. However, individuals with psoriasis would not present with proximal muscle weakness. Moreover, the image of the patient’s hands lacks the silvery plaques that characterize psoriasis.
✅ Purplish discoloration of the eyelids:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Wide reddish-purple streaks on the abdomen:
Incorrect: Abdominal striae can be seen in patients with hypercortisolism. In patients with chronic hypercortisolism, the skin becomes progressively thinner and can no longer conceal the color of venous blood in the underlying dermis. Chronic hypercortisolism can also cause muscle atrophy and weakness. Although this patient is taking budesonide, inhaled corticosteroids are generally unable to cause systemic hypercortisolism and the manifestation of striae.
❌ Pruritic eruptions on the body’s skin flexures:
Incorrect: This finding would be observed in patients with atopic dermatitis, colloquially known as eczema. The condition most often affects flexural surfaces (e.g., antecubital fossa, popliteal fossa). However, it would be atypical for eczema to cause proximal muscle weakness or the lesions observed on the dorsum of the patient’s hands.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to the outpatient provider for evaluation of muscle weakness that began 5 months ago. The patient reports having difficulty at work as a librarian reaching for books on the top shelves. Past medical history is notable for hypertension currently managed with lisinopril. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 148/91 mmHg, pulse is 64/min, and respiratory rate is 14/min. Physical examination reveals 4/5 strength in the deltoids and quadriceps. Strength is 5/5 in the rest of the body. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal examination are non-contributory. No rashes are found on examination. Which of the following findings is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: Detection of anti-signal recognition particle antibodies
Perimysial infiltration pattern on muscle biopsy
Detection of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies

questions.solution:
This patient has polymyositis, which presents with proximal muscle weakness in the absence of skin findings. The symptoms of polymyositis overlap with those of the other idiopathic inflammatory myopathies (e.g., dermatomyositis, inclusion body myositis). A combination of the patient’s history, physical examination, and laboratory testing can be used to diagnose patients with polymyositis and distinguish it from similar conditions.  

Definitive diagnosis is based on identifying autoantibodies, like anti-signal recognition particle (anti-SRP), and anti-Jo-1 antibodies. Of note, anti-SRP is most specific for polymyositis whereas anti-Mi-2 is most specific for dermatomyositis. Anti-Jo-1 antibodies are non-specific and are often found in patients with either condition. All of the inflammatory myopathies can cause elevated serum levels of muscle enzymes such as aldolase or creatine kinase. Additionally, electromyography can be used to detect regions of dead muscle cells that cause abnormal electrical signals conduction. A muscle biopsy will show inflammation, immune cell infiltration, and varying stages of necrosis. Biopsy in a patient with polymyositis will reveal endomysial infiltration by CD8+ T-cells. In contrast, biopsy in a patient with dermatomyositis will reveal perimysial infiltration by CD4+ T-cells. 




Option Analysis

❌ Elevation of serum creatinine kinase:
Incorrect: Increased serum creatinine kinase levels would be expected in pathologies that cause muscle injury. These conditions include trauma, rhabdomyolysis, and autoimmune myopathies such as dermatomyositis and polymyositis. However, this finding is non-specific and would have limited utility in distinguishing the patient’s condition (polymyositis) from other conditions with a similar presentation.
✅ Detection of anti-signal recognition particle antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Detection of anti-Mi-2 antibodies:
Incorrect: Autoantibodies targeting the Mi-2 nuclear antigen are most specific for dermatomyositis. This condition also presents with proximal muscle weakness. However, dermatomyositis presents with skin findings, whereas this patient's physical examination revealed none.
❌ Perimysial infiltration pattern on muscle biopsy:
Incorrect: A muscle biopsy can be useful in the work-up of dermatomyositis and polymyositis. A perimysial infiltration pattern, where immune cells invade the connective tissue sheath that groups muscle fibers into bundles, is found in patients with dermatomyositis. In contrast, the patient in this vignette has polymyositis, which results in endomysial infiltration. 
❌ Detection of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies:
Incorrect: Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) is found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Patients with rheumatoid arthritis can present with morning stiffness. The condition most often affects distal joints (e.g., metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, wrist, knee). In contrast, it would be atypical for rheumatoid arthritis to present with muscle tenderness and weakness at the shoulders and hips.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman is evaluated by the outpatient physician for 5-months of generalized fatigue and diffuse soft-tissue pain. The pain is present in the upper extremities, lower extremities, and back. She feels tired every morning despite getting adequate sleep in the evening. Past medical history is notable for hypertension that is currently managed with propranolol. Temperature is 37.2°C (98.9°F), blood pressure is 136/88 mmHg, pulse is 61/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min. Physical examination reveals 5/5 strength and full range-of-motion in the upper and lower extremities. Soft-tissue tenderness is elicited at multiple locations across the patient’s body. Laboratory results are as follows:  

 
Laboratory value  Result
 Hemoglobin  14.8 g/dL 
 Leukocyte  7,800/mm3 
 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR)   7 mm/h 
 Serum creatinine kinase  27 U/L 
 Antinuclear antibodies  Negative 

Which of the following additional findings would most likely be found in this patient?

choices.text: Facial rash exacerbated by sunlight exposure
Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine
Improvement of symptoms with medication cessation

questions.solution:
This patient has fibromyalgia, a condition caused by abnormal pain perception. The exact mechanism of abnormal pain perception is uncertain and likely multimodal, but various studies have determined that patients have an exaggerated pain response to pain stimuli, altered brain structure, and altered neurotransmitter function. The condition is most often diagnosed in women between 20-50 years-old. Fibromyalgia often runs in families, so there appears to be a strong genetic component to the disease. Pyschological trauma like child abuse is also linked to fibromyalgia.  

Patients with fibromyalgia present with chronic widespread pain that most often present at points where muscles attach to the bone. These are called “tender points.” The tender points are spread throughout the patient’s body and lack the localized patterns found in conditions such as polymyositis/dermatomyositis (proximal tenderness) or ankylosing spondylosis (spinal tenderness).  

In addition, cognitive disturbances are present in the majority of patients. Patients may present with fatigue, headaches, unrefreshing sleep, and difficulty concentrating. The cognitive disturbances are often referred to as "fibro fog." Patients commonly describe problems with attention and difficulty doing tasks that require rapid thought changes. Psychiatric symptoms are also common in patients with fibromyalgia, with depression and/or anxiety present in 30 to 50% of patients at the time of diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Jaw pain exacerbated by chewing:
Incorrect: Patients with temporal arteritis can have jaw pain that is exacerbated by chewing. Temporal arteritis is associated with polymyalgia rheumatica, which causes pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips, as well as elevated ESR levels. In contrast, this patient has diffuse tenderness affecting both proximal and distal joints and normal ESR levels, suggesting a different diagnosis.
❌ Facial rash exacerbated by sunlight exposure:
Incorrect: A malar rash may be present in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis presents with proximal muscle tenderness and weakness. In contrast, this patient has full strength throughout. Moreover, the patient has diffuse pain, as opposed to the localized symptoms observed in dermatomyositis. SLE can also be ruled out due to the negative antinuclear antibodies (ANA) titers.
✅ Difficulty concentrating at work :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Reduced range of motion in the lumbar spine:
Incorrect: Patients with ankylosing spondylitis often have limited range of motion in the spine. The condition most often affects young men. Pain and tenderness is localized to the affected patient’s back. It would be atypical for ankylosing spondylitis to present with the diffuse soft-tissue tenderness noted in this patient.
❌ Improvement of symptoms with medication cessation:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers such as propranolol can cause fatigue and drowsiness as side effects. This phenomenon may potentially explain why the patient reports feeling tired despite getting adequate sleep. However, diffuse soft-tissue/joint pain is not a side effect of beta-blockers. As a result, discontinuing propranolol will likely have little effect on the patient’s symptoms.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old woman comes to her primary care physician for evaluation of visual changes. She reports having blurry vision that is more pronounced at the end of the day. The symptom started gradually around 3 months ago and has been progressing over time. The patient was recently diagnosed with an anterior mediastinal mass via chest CT. She consumes a diet rich in fresh vegetables and meats. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min and blood pressure is 118/75 mmHg. Physical examination reveals weakness in the extraocular muscles. When the patient is asked to look upwards toward the ceiling for 60 seconds, she notes double vision after 40 seconds, which resolves after several minutes of rest. Visual acuity and pupillary reflexes are normal. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.


Which of the following structures at the neuromuscular junction is most likely affected in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
The patient has extraocular muscle weakness that worsens with repeated activity and improves with rest. These findings are concerning for myasthenia gravis (MG). MG is often associated with thymic abnormalities (e.g., thymic hyperplasia or thymoma), as seen in this patient with recent diagnosis of mediastinal mass on CT scan.  

MG is a type II hypersensitivity reaction that develops when B-cells begin producing antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors on muscle cells. Myasthenia gravis causes muscle weakness via two mechanisms. First, the antibodies block the binding of ACh to its receptors. Second, the antibodies can activate the classical complement pathway, resulting in destruction of ACh receptors.

Due to the reduced number of available ACh receptors, ACh released at the nerve terminal is unable to generate the postsynaptic potential needed to induce muscle contraction, resulting in muscle weakness. The weakness is more pronounced with the repeated use of a muscle group, since it causes depletion of the ACh store in the neuromuscular junction.  

A minority of people with MG produce another type of antibody against muscle-specific tyrosine kinase (MuSK). This antibody attacks proteins within myocytes and also results in impaired muscle cell activity.  

Option Analysis

❌ Structure A  :
Incorrect: This patient with ptosis, diplopia and extraocular muscle weakness most likely has MG, which occurs due to the formation of auto-antibodies against postsynaptic ACh receptors. In contrast, structure A is a presynaptic mitochondria, which plays no role in the pathogenesis of MG.
❌ Structure B:
Incorrect: Structure B is a presynaptic vesicle containing ACh. Botulinum toxin works by inhibiting extravasation of these vesicles into the synaptic cavity, thereby inhibiting the release of ACh. Clinically, it can manifest as diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, and dyspnea. It is unlikely in this patient without any risk factors (e.g. ingestion of expired canned foods).
✅ Structure C:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Structure D:
Incorrect: Structure D is a presynaptic calcium channel. Patients with Lambert Eaton myasthenic syndrome develop auto-antibodies against this structure. The condition manifests with muscle weakness that temporarily improves with activity. However, this patient has ptosis that is elicited by prolonged upwards gaze, which suggests that her muscle weakness is worsened with activity. This finding is more consistent with MG.
❌ Structure E:
Incorrect: Structure E is a vesicle that has fused with the cellular membrane and is releasing ACh into the neuromuscular junction. As mentioned before, botulinum toxin impairs this process and can manifest with flaccid muscle paralysis, diplopia, dysarthria, and/or dysphagia.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to his primary care physician for evaluation of intermittent muscle weakness that began around three months ago. He reports having episodes of “seeing-double” and having difficulty chewing that occur in the evening and resolve the next morning. Past medical history is notable for asthma, for which he intermittently uses an albuterol inhaler. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 65/min and blood pressure is 122/71 mmHg. During the physical examination, the patient is asked to look upwards toward the ceiling for 60 seconds. This maneuver elicits bilateral diplopia. The remainder of the examination is noncontributory. Workup is sent to confirm the diagnosis, and the patient is started on the first-line medication for his condition. Which of the following is a likely side-effect from overdose of this medication?
questions.solution:
This patient has oculobulbar muscle weakness that worsens after prolonged activity and improves with rest, which is most consistent with myasthenia gravis (MG). Patients with MG develop auto-antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine (ACh) receptors. These antibodies can block and destroy the receptors.

First-line therapy consists of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine, pyridostigmine). These drugs prevent acetylcholinesterase from degrading ACh, which increases ACh concentration at the neuromuscular junction and subsequently counteracts the effects of ACh receptor antibodies.

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors can cause adverse effects related to nicotinic and muscarinic overstimulation, the two receptors for ACh. Side effects include muscular weakness and fasciculations, bradycardia, diaphoresis, hypersalivation, and miosis. The side-effects can be managed by using an antimuscarinic agent (e.g. scopolamine).

Immunosuppressive drugs (e.g. steroids), intravenous immunoglobulin therapy, and plasmapheresis can also be used in the treatment of severe MG by reducing serum auto-antibody levels. Lastly, many patients with MG undergo thymectomy (surgical removal of the thymus), which can improve symptoms even if the patient has no issues with the thymus itself.  





Option Analysis

❌ Pupillary dilation:
Incorrect: Pupillary dilation, also termed mydriasis, is a side effect of anticholinergic medications (e.g., atropine, oxybutynin, and scopolamine). Additional side-effects include increased body temperature, dry and flushed skin, urinary retention, and altered mental status. However, the patient in this vignette has oculobulbar muscle weakness that worsens with use, which raises concerns for MG. Anticholinergic drugs are not used in the treatment of this condition.
✅ Muscle fasciculations:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Elevated bleeding risk:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis can be used to treat MG by removing auto-antibodies against nicotinic acetylcholine receptors from the patient’s bloodstream. The procedure can also deplete coagulation factors and increase bleeding risk. However, plasmapheresis is not the first-line treatment option for MG.
❌ Urinary retention:
Incorrect: Urinary retention is a side effect of anticholinergic medications. Additional side-effects associated with this medication class include increased body temperature, dry and flushed skin, cycloplegia/mydriasis, and altered mental status. However, the patient in this vignette has oculobulbar muscle weakness that worsens with use, which raises concern for myasthenia gravis. Anticholinergic drugs are not used in the treatment of this condition.
❌ Increased muscle breakdown:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids, such as prednisone and methylprednisolone, can be administered to treat MG. The medication can increase the rate of muscle breakdown. However, corticosteroids are generally not used as the first-line treatment option. Instead, they are used in patients who remain symptomatic after treatment with a cholinomimetic agent.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man comes to the office due to leg pain for the past few months. He reports pain that is 3/10 in severity, tingling, and located on the buttocks and thighs. The pain is exacerbated with walking or standing for prolonged time. The patient noticed however, a relief in the pain when he is walking with a supermarket cart or when sitting. Medical history is notable for type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which the patient takes metformin. He has no dyspnea or chest pain. He has been smoking 1 pack of cigarettes per day for 30 years. Vitals are within normal limits. On physical examination, peripheral pulses are intact. Neurologic examination is within normal limits. Which of the following structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with posterior leg pain and tingling which exacerbates with standing or walking erect and subside with sitting or walking with a cart (leaning forward). This presentation is consistent with lumbar spinal stenosis (LLS).  

LLS refers to narrowing of the intraspinal (central) canal at the lumbar region, which can be congenital or acquired. Compression of the spinal cord is responsible for the pain, weakness, and paresthesia symptoms during walking (termed neurogenic claudication). In general, extension of the spine (e.g., standing, going downhill) narrows the intraspinal canal and exacerbates symptoms. In contrast, flexion of the spine (e.g., sitting, walking with cart) widens the intraspinal canal and improves symptoms. This characteristic can be used to distinguish LSS from vascular claudication, which is not posture dependent.  

Spondylosis (degenerative arthritis of the spine) is the most common cause of LSS and commonly affects individuals over the age of 60 years. Some factors that may contribute to this process include disc degeneration and protrusion, loss of disc height, facet joint arthropathy, osteophyte formation, and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy. Of note, the ligamentum flavum is an elastic ligament that runs from the axis to the sacrum.  



Option Analysis

❌ Supraspinous ligament:
Incorrect: The supraspinous ligament connects the apices of the spinous processes from the cervical vertebra to the sacrum and limits spine flexion. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of spinal stenosis.
❌ Anterior longitudinal ligament:
Incorrect: The anterior longitudinal ligament is located on the anterior side of the vertebrae. Its role is to limit spine extension. It is not involved in the pathogenesis of spinal stenosis.
✅ Ligamentum flavum:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Peripheral arteries:
Incorrect: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) can cause vascular claudication, which causes symptoms due to insufficient blood supply to the peripheral tissues. Although this patient has risk factors for PAD, the peripheral pulses are intact. Moreover, the symptoms worsen while standing still and improve when walking with a cart. Patients with PAD will report exacerbation with exertion and improvement with rest.
❌ Sacroiliac joint:
Incorrect: Ankylosing spondylitis is an inflammatory autoimmune condition that affects the spine and sacroiliac joints. Patients often endorse morning stiffness that alleviates with movement, limited spine flexion, and back pain. It most commonly affects men between the ages of 30-50 years old. Extra-axial involvement such as uveitis and aortic regurgitation may also occur.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents to his primary care physician to evaluate low back pain. The patient was helping his sibling lift furniture yesterday when he experienced acute onset low back pain, requiring him to lay in bed the remainder of the day. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. The patient has tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine on physical examination. Strength is 5/5 with foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion in the right lower extremity, while 4/5 in the left lower extremity. Sensation is also diminished on the lateral aspect of the left lower extremity compared to that of the right side. Which of the following is the most likely affected nerve root responsible for this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient with low back pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot with associated diminished foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, and foot inversion and eversion is most likely suffering from L5 radiculopathy.  

Lumbar and cervical disc herniations are common musculoskeletal back pathologies that result from herniation of the nucleus pulposus and compression of the nerve root. In general, symptoms include focal back pain with associated radiation of pain, weakness, and sensory disturbance in the anatomic distribution of the compromised nerve root. Overall, the most common site of lumbar disc herniation is the L4-L5 vertebral level, which produces symptoms of pain and loss of sensation down the lateral aspect of the leg into the foot with associated weakness in foot dorsiflexion, toe extension, foot inversion, and foot eversion.  



In the cervical spine, the most common site of disc herniation is the C6-C7 vertebral level, which compresses the C7 nerve root. Herniation at this site presents with pain in the neck, shoulder, middle finger, and hand, along with weakness with elbow and wrist extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion. 

Option Analysis

❌ C7:
Incorrect: A disc herniation at C6-C7 would result in C7 nerve root compression, causing pain in the neck, shoulder, middle finger, and hand, as well as weakness with elbow and wrist extension, forearm pronation, and wrist flexion.  
❌ T10:
Incorrect: Thoracic disc herniation is overall uncommon compared to lumbar or cervical disc herniation. A lesion at this site would result in pain that radiates towards the umbilicus.  
❌ L2-L4:
Incorrect: L2-L4 radiculopathy often presents with pain and diminished sensation radiating down the anterior aspect of the thigh and occasionally into the medial part of the lower leg with associated weakness of hip flexion, knee extension, and hip adduction.  
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ S1:
Incorrect: S1 radiculopathy presents with pain and diminished sensation that radiates down the posterior aspect of the leg, with associated weakness of plantar flexion, leg extension, and knee flexion, along with a reduced ankle jerk reflex.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to back pain and leg weakness. Two hours ago, the patient lifted a heavy box and suddenly felt severe back pain that radiates down to the toes. He reports chronic back pain for the past 2 years but has never experienced pain so severe. An MRI is obtained and reveals a posterolateral disc herniation at the level of the intervertebral disk between L4 and L5 vertebrae. Which of the following nerve roots would most likely be affected by this injury?
questions.solution:
Disc herniation is one of the most common causes of lumbosacral radiculopathy. The disc is composed of the inner nucleus pulposus and outer annulus fibrosus. In disc herniation, the nucleus pulposus extrudes through the annulus fibrosus into the vertebral canal, causing mechanical compression of the spinal cord and inflammation.  

The lumbosacral spine is especially susceptible to disc herniations because of its mobility. Up to 95% of injuries occur at the L4-L5 and L5-S1 levels. The lumbar and sacral spinal nerve roots exit the spinal cord at the T12-L1 vertebral level, where the spinal cord tapers as the conus medullaris. The nerves then travel down the canal as the cauda equina and exit at their respective neural foramina. The nerves can be compressed anywhere along their course depending on the type of herniation, size, and location. The most common type of herniation is posterolateral (paracentral), less common central, and rare far lateral. With the exception of C1-7 nerves, which exit above the corresponding vertebrae, and C8, which exit below C7, the rest of the spinal nerves exit below their corresponding vertebrae. Due to these reasons, a posterolateral disc herniation at the level of L4-5 vertebrae will compress the L5 nerve.




Option Analysis

❌ L3:
Incorrect: The L3 nerve root exits the spinal canal below the L3 vertebrae and therefore is spared.
❌ L4:
Incorrect: The L4 nerve root exits below L4 vertebrae and can be injured in far lateral disc protrusion but these are rare, and this patient has a posterolateral disc herniation.
✅ L5:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ S1:
Incorrect: The S1 nerve root exits the spinal canal below the L5 vertebrae at the sacral foramina. It can be compressed by L5-S1 disc protrusion rather than L4-L5 disc protrusion.
❌ S2:
Incorrect: Structural radiculopathies of the S2, S3, or S4 levels are far less common than those affecting other levels. They may occur, however, due to large central disc herniations that compress the nerve roots intrathecally at higher levels.
